posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked:
First time Swerve user, LONG time programmer.

Our swerve test bed uses SDS Mk2 modules and we are using the Command based Swerve code from FRC0ToAutonomous/#6 Swerve Drive Auto at master · SeanSun6814/FRC0ToAutonomous · GitHub as our starting point.

Our modues have been calibrated and drive correctly Fwd/Rev, Left/Right and Rotate. We had to invert the NavX1 gyro to get +ve CCW rotation. We also have the Field Centric driving working, although we had to re-invert the heading to get it to run correctly (possible clue here)

The sample code has odometry and the measurments seem to be correct, with the ONE exception that the Y axis incerases when we move Right.

It might normally be an easy fix just to flip the Y some how, EXCEPT that we have also integrated April Tag Pose Estimation from PhotonVision, and the AprilTag coordinate system has got Y increasing to the LEFT as X increases moving forward.  This is based on the defined field coordinate system.  So when the robot hcan see a tag, the X & Y movement is correct, and as soon as they go out of sight, the Y starts running in the wrong direction.

I’ve tried multiple things to get the Y axis to flip, but everything I do just has another side effect. I’ve tried, a) changing swerve module wheel orientations & inversions, b) flipping heading rotation direction in odometry module.  I even turned off moduleoptimization to see if this was confusing things…

My basic questions are:

Does this sound familar to anyone?  I’m looking for a known fix, rather than some “ideas” or “sugestions” for things to try…  I’m getting worn out.

or

Is there a better “Command Based” Swerve example with Odometry, to start from that uses the correct X and Y field axes?

link_counts.title: FRC0ToAutonomous/#6 Swerve Drive Auto at master · SeanSun6814/FRC0ToAutonomous · GitHub

posts.cooked: My team had this issue when our swerve modules had their angle as clockwise, not counterclockwise like it should be. It could also be module coordinates

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
First question: Is your full code public? I see that you’re using the 0toauto framework code for swerve but there are undoubtedly things you have changed that might affect this. One thing you should try is making sure turning the modules CCW does indeed make the encoders measure positive numbers, they might be flipped. We had a similar issue and it was due to this.

Second question: Are you using a NEO swerve or a Falcon swerve? If you’re using a Falcon swerve I can recommend BaseFalconSwerve as a good starting point. If you’re using NEO’s you can still use BFS but you will have to modify the code a bit to get it to work.

posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked:
Since the drive workd, I did not check if the modules had correct CCW rotation.  In checking the code, they DO have the invert option turned on the Absolute encoders…  Will definately check this.

Thanks for the specific clue.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked: I’m talking about both encoders, they should be CCW+. I’ll take a look at your code when im free.

posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked:
I had about an hour to do some tests.  I rotated the Swerve Modules and saw that the angle increased when I rotated them CW.  So they needed to be reversed.

So I cleared the existing InvertAbsoluteAngleEncoder flag on each module (changed from true to false).

I then cleared the angle offset for each module, built and loaded the new code and proceeded to re measure/calibrate the angle offsets for each module.  This is where the trouble started.  I entered the new encoder offsets, built and deployed the code.  Now the wheels did not face forward when sent to 0 degrees.  They ended up pointing in a whole new set of weird angles.

I did the whole process again, and got a new set of offset values???

I even tried negating the offset values.  No good.

I then ran out of time.   I put the old code/offsets back, and the robot was drivable again.

Both Encoders ??  I see where to invert the abs encoder, but not the steering motor encoder.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
You just invert the steering motor in general. You have this line here:

You need to negate that variable. It seems to come from your DriveConstants so you just negate all those. It seems your absolute encoders are CW+ so you also negate that in the DriveConstants class. You need to make sure that both the relative and absolute steering encoders are set to be CCW+. Once you do that you can tune the offsets. I recommend using glass for this but you can do whatever you want.

You should also call the resetEncoders() method every once in a while when you are not rotating the swerve modules and are standing still.

Also this is a bit of a side note but when you run driveMotor.set(state.speedMetersPerSecond / ModuleConstants.kPhysicalMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond); you’re not actually setting it to go to the right speed just setting to run at x% of it’s power which doesn’t directly translate to the right speed. This will be an issue in the future so just keep that in mind.

Btw if you want more “immediate help” you can contact me on discord: Rezq#8253 and i’ll be able to help you out faster. I might be able to call too at some point.

posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked:
Thanks.

I will give this a bash as soon as I get access again. I just came beck from the Chesapeake District FTC regional with my G-FORCE FTC team.

No advancement to Worlds :(, but now I can focus on the FRC software team

posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked:
Thanks to input from tyhf21 and super help from @Rezq I got my swerve drive working.  It turned out there were several issues, mainly steming from the fact that the original code seems to assume a different coordinate system, and that I didn’t fully understand how the various motors and encoders needed to be configured.

I also didn’t understand the relationship between the turning motor encoder and the Absolute position encoder. @Rezq ’s tip to call the resetEncoders() showed me that the AbsoluteEncoder is only read when resetting the motor encoders, and that’s the one I need to read to get a correct wheel offset (which must be positive).

So I went thought and verified the fwd/CCW direction or all the motors and encoders and then set the propper invert constants.  I also had to correct the swerve module positions (they were assuming +Y to the right). and then I could use the correct +CCW gyro reading throughout.

The stars aligned and now all the axes are correct and the code moves seamlessly from standard Odometry to Vision Based Localization.  Now I’m looking at whether I can take drift out of the gyro by reading the Theta of the vision targets.  First look says it should work well.  My main concern is that FIRST chose the lowest reliability version of AprilTags.  with only 5 error correction bits, false positives are a real concern.  FTC uses 11 bits and so it’s almost impossible to get a false positive.

Anyway… now it’s on to dynamic path planning.  Oh, and we’re switching to a new Swerve Module :eyeroll:

Thanks again.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
Great to hear its working now!

Anyway… now it’s on to dynamic path planning. Oh, and we’re switching to a new Swerve Module :eyeroll:

lol dw switching to a new module isn’t as hard as it seems. As always if you need help just lmk on discord.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
PhilBot:

The stars aligned and now all the axes are correct and the code moves seamlessly from standard Odometry to Vision Based Localization. Now I’m looking at whether I can take drift out of the gyro by reading the Theta of the vision targets. First look says it should work well. My main concern is that FIRST chose the lowest reliability version of AprilTags. with only 5 error correction bits, false positives are a real concern. FTC uses 11 bits and so it’s almost impossible to get a false positive.

Also, you should try using SwerveDrivePoseEstimator isntead of just odometry reset with vision measurements. This seamlessly combines odometry and vision measurements and is a lot more reliable than using either one individually or switching between the two. (not sure if you’re already doing that and i’m misunderstanding what’s going on)

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Rezq:

isntead of just odometry reset with vision measurements

That’s actually what the pose estimator does internally (it has an odometry instance). The pose estimator has extra logic to do a weighted average in SE(3) between the odometry and vision pose, and a pose buffer used to compensate for CV latency (like what 254’s 2016 robot did).

They’re designed to be API-compatible, and if you don’t use the pose estimator’s addVisionMeasurement(), it’s basically just a wrapper around odometry class calls.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked: Yea that’s exactly what i’m saying. I’m recommending he uses the pose estimator class instead of just the odometry class with his own way of resting with vision.

posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked: I am using pose estimator here, right?

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked: Yes you’re using pose estimators correctly I just wanted to make sure you weren’t wrapping the SwerveDriveOdometry class manually and then filtering in vision measurements somehow.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: My team had a similar issue and the solution was to make the get CCW heading function return negative and the get CW function to return positive. If that doesn’t work, try swapping signs.

posts.name: Jason Evans
posts.cooked: You likely are running into a slightly simpler problem than what this thread discussed (swerve drive module rotation direction). WPLlib uses a coordinate system closely tied to polar coordinates. Specifically, robot-relative coordinates treat “forward” as the positive x axis, and angles increase in the counter-clockwise direction. You will get mystifying problems if you instead think that the robot’s “forward” is the positive y axis and/or angles increase in the clockwise direction.

link_counts.title: Swerve X and Y Flipped in Odometry

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
j.e:

WPLlib uses a coordinate system closely tied to polar coordinates. Specifically, robot-relative coordinates treat “forward” as the positive x axis, and angles increase in the counter-clockwise direction.

WPILib’s coordinate system has nothing to do with polar coordinates, actually. It uses the North-West-Up (NWU) coordinate axes convention. This is the same one used in math class where angles are measured CCW from the +x axis. What confuses people is that in 2D math classes, +y is oriented forward, but that’s not where angles are measured from.

link_counts.title: Coordinate Systems — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
